title: Uncertain road ahead for UK's car manufacturers despite first rise in production for 15 months
text:
Car production increased by 3.3 per cent last month, the first rise in over a year, new figures show.

A total of 92,158 cars were built in August, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said.

It was the first increase in 15 months, mainly because several plants brought forward planned summer shutdowns to April to guard against a possible Brexit in March.

Production drive: A total of 92,158 cars were built in August, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said

Just over 2,900 more cars were produced in August than in the same month last year, but this was not enough to compensate for April’s 56,999-unit loss, resulting in a 17 per cent deficit so far in 2019.

A total of 866,918 cars were produced in the first eight months of the year, the first time output has dipped below a million units in the period since 2014.

Mike Hawes, SMMT chief executive, said: ‘While growth is always welcome, the figures mask the underlying downward trend and strengthening global headwinds facing the sector.

‘The mere threat of No Deal has undermined investment and the potential imposition of tariffs, border delays and additional administrative burdens would damage competitiveness.’

Commentating on the results, Stuart Apperley, director and head of UK automotive at Lloyds Bank Commercial Banking, said the industry would have to wait for the 'dust to settle' before it becomes clear if the rise is a temporary spike as September is a difficult month to analyse.

This is because production is inflated, especially for the home market, due to the arrival of the registration plate changeover increasing demand for new models.

He also predicted another year-on-year rise next month due to the markedly difficult September period in 2018, with outputs falling due to significant supply disruption caused by the introduction of the new WLTP emission test cycle that month.
